properties.name: alignment
properties.description: Specifies the horizontal alignment of the list level. The value can be 'Left', 'Centered', or 'Right'.

examples.description: Set the alignment of the first list level to centered for the first list in the document

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the request context from a ListLevel object to verify the connection between the add-in and Word application before performing operations on the list level.

properties.name: font
properties.description: Gets a Font object that represents the character formatting of the specified object.

examples.description: Set the list level font to bold, blue, and 14pt size for the first list in the document.

properties.name: linkedStyle
properties.description: Specifies the name of the style that's linked to the specified list level object.

examples.description: Link a list level to a character style named "ListBullet" to apply consistent formatting across list items.

properties.name: numberFormat
properties.description: Specifies the number format for the specified list level.

examples.description: Set the number format of the first list level to use uppercase Roman numerals (I, II, III, etc.)

properties.name: numberPosition
properties.description: Specifies the position (in points) of the number or bullet for the specified list level object.

examples.description: Set the number position to 36 points for the first level of the first list in the document

properties.name: numberStyle
properties.description: Specifies the number style for the list level object.

examples.description: Set the number style of the first list level to uppercase Roman numerals (I, II, III, IV, etc.)

properties.name: resetOnHigher
properties.description: Specifies the list level that must appear before the specified list level restarts numbering at 1.

examples.description: Configure a list level so that it restarts numbering at 1 whenever a higher-level list item (level 0) appears before it.

properties.name: startAt
properties.description: Specifies the starting number for the specified list level object.

examples.description: Set the starting number of the first list level to 5 so the numbered list begins at 5 instead of 1

properties.name: tabPosition
properties.description: Specifies the tab position for the specified list level object.

examples.description: Set the tab position to 1 inch (72 points) for the first level of the first list in the document

properties.name: textPosition
properties.description: Specifies the position (in points) for the second line of wrapping text for the specified list level object.

examples.description: Set the text position (second line indent) to 36 points for the first level of the first list in the document

properties.name: trailingCharacter
properties.description: Specifies the character inserted after the number for the specified list level.

examples.description: Set the trailing character after the number to a tab for the first level of the first list in the document

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

examples.description: Load and display the alignment property of the first list level in the first list of the document

methods.name: set
methods.description: Sets multiple properties of an object at the same time. You can pass either a plain object with the appropriate properties, or another API object of the same type.

examples.description: Configure multiple formatting properties of the first list level in the first list, setting its alignment to right, number format to uppercase letters, and starting number to 5.

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). (JSON.stringify, in turn, calls the toJSON method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original Word.ListLevel object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.ListLevelData) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

examples.description: Get the list level properties as a plain JavaScript object and log it to the console for debugging purposes.

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject). If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the par

examples.description: Track a list level object to maintain its reference across multiple sync calls when modifying list formatting properties in different batches
